intro: Quercus consobrina, commonly known as the Mexican white oak, is a deciduous tree native to central and southern Mexico. It belongs to the Fagaceae family and is characterized by its broad, lobed leaves that turn yellow in the fall. The tree produces small, cup-shaped acorns that are an important food source for various wildlife species. Quercus consobrina typically grows in dry to moist forests and is known for its durable, heavy wood. Its botanical features make it an ecologically significant plant in its native habitat.
